thread.title: Armada still searching for a road win as season nears end
thread.title_full: Armada still searching for a road win as season nears end

author: Clayton Freeman
title: Armada still searching for a road win as season nears end
text:
Armada still searching for a road win as season nears end 
By Clayton Freeman Sat, Oct 24, 2015 @ 7:06 pm | updated Sat, Oct 24, 2015 @ 7:09 pm Photos Fran Ruchalski/ For the Florida Times-Union Akeil Barrett redirects the ball in the first half of the Armada game as they took on the Ottawa Fury on Wednesday, October 21, 2015. 
Two matches remain in the Jacksonville Armada’s inaugural North American Soccer League season, and the time has come for a soccer edition of Maritime Math. 
For the Armada, the magic number has been 904: All eight of the club’s NASL victories have come at home. 
The distance from the Baseball Grounds of Jacksonville to Clarke Field in Edmonton: 2,260 miles, as the Canada goose flies. That’s not home. 
And that brings up the number, so little and yet so big, that looms over the Armada’s season. 
In seven months and 14 games across nine states and provinces, the expansion club has won … 
Zero. Nil. 0-for-2015. 
“It’s incredible to me, with the talent that we have, that we haven’t been able to win away,” goalkeeper Miguel Gallardo said. “We’ve played some games where we’ve deserved more.” 
The last chance of the season comes Sunday afternoon, when the Armada finishes its away schedule against FC Edmonton. 
The 2013 Edmonton squad is the only team in the North American Soccer League’s modern era to complete an entire season without winning away from home. 
By Sunday night, the Armada — 0-12-2 in its 14 road games this season — could join them. 
Not the kind of history the Armada, which set a league attendance record of 16,164 in its first-ever match with Edmonton at EverBank Field on April 4, had in mind. 
Jacksonville has been outscored 20-2 in its nine fall season road games, all losses. 
A win Sunday would not only allow the Armada to avoid the dubious distinction of a winless road campaign, it would also complete an improbable sweep. Jacksonville topped Edmonton 3-1 in the season opener, then charged from behind for a 3-2 victory on Oct. 17 despite playing down a man for 40 minutes. 
The Armada’s resilient showing gives Gallardo plenty of confidence ahead of a rematch only eight days later. 
“We’re all going in with a positive mindset, knowing we’re playing a team we beat two times,” he said. 
Edmonton has seen its own numbers turn sour, getting mathematically eliminated from postseason contention by the loss to the Armada and drawing fewer than 3,000 fans per game, by far the lowest average in the NASL. 
Another bonus for Jacksonville is the return of top scorer Alhassane Keita, who tormented the Edmonton defense last week but received his second red card of the year. 
Although Wednesday’s 3-1 loss to the fall season champion Ottawa Fury extinguished the Armada’s flickering playoff hopes, the players are optimistic that they’ll erase the zero from the away win column Sunday. 
“We’ve got to get that monkey off our backs,” Gallardo said. “It’s a great opportunity for us to go out there and break that cycle.”
